awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Remote Imaging of Community Ecology via Animal-borne Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will construct a wireless network of animal-borne embedded devices that will be deployed and tested in a biologically-relevant application. The networked devices will provide not only geo-location data, but also execute cooperative strategies that save battery-life by selectively recording bandwidth-intensive audio and high-definition video footage of occurrences of animal group behavior of interest, such as predation. 
This project comprises three concurrent and interdependent research themes. The first is the investigation of methods to design and analyze the performance of distributed algorithms that implement autonomous decisions at the mobile agents, subject to communication and computational constraints. The second will pursue data-driven fundamental research on the modeling of animal group motion and will promote a formal understanding of the mechanisms of social interaction. The third is centered on the investigation of methods for hardware integration to build distributed networks of embedded devices that are capable of executing the newly developed algorithms, subject to power and weight constraints. 
The results and experience gained in this project will guide the development of effective autonomous systems for the monitoring and protection of endangered species. This project will create undergraduate and graduate research opportunities at all participating institutions, expanding on an existing collaboration between the University of Maryland, Princeton University, and the National Geographic Society. There is the potential for using wide-reaching media resources to disseminate the results of this project to a broad audience. This may contribute to attracting more students to engineering and science.

por.por_cntn:
We have contributed to the development of a wireless network of animal-borne embedded devices to record biologically relevant video, geo-location, and other sensor data.  We developed models and theories for the collective dynamics of animal groups, notably herding dynamics and predator-prey dynamics, that make rigorous the way individual behaviors and interactions connect to group-level behaviors and make possible efficient strategies for deployment and operation of the wireless network.  Modeling and predictive skill of animal group dynamics contributes to a closed-loop strategy for making efficient observations of the animals in the wild.  We provided extensive training of students in cyber-physical systems research, which required an integration of disciplines, and we have engaged the general public as well as school children in the excitement, opportunities, and impact of this type of research.

We derived a dynamic model and performed analyses of the evasion strategies and collective dynamics of heterogeneous herds, and multi-agent networks networks more generally, under the threat of a single pursuer.  The model incorporates interactions and tensions among prey and tensions between predator and prey.  It is informed by observational data, biological insights, and the rigorous application of system theoretic methods.   The model provides a principled approach to deepening our understanding of the relationship between strategies used by individuals and the outcome in terms of the motion and spatial distribution of the group, successful evasion, and capture of prey.

We developed the means to account for key heterogeneous constraints on mobility of individual agents:  limits on speed, turning rate, and lateral acceleration. We proved a pursuer strategy of optimal target selection, which leads to capture in bounded time.  For evaders, we proved that any evader not initially targeted has the ability to avoid capture using a reactive evasion strategy. We studied optimal strategies for agents with radius-limited sensing capabilities, proving conditions for evader capture avoidance through a local strategy of risk reduction. We analyzed video data of zebra herds evading a remote-controlled “robo-lion”; these first-of-their-kind data were collected at the Mpala Research Centre in Kenya. We used the data and analysis to understand the evasion of a social group from a single predator.

We used the model to examine how groups form so quickly when they are initially at rest and widely distributed. We have also used the model to understand the role of heterogeneity among individuals and the ways in which animals specialize their roles for safety and efficiency. Importantly, we can use the dynamics and critical conditions for predicting collective behavior, which in turn informs the design of strategies that trigger crittercams for efficient use of high-resolution sampling.

To complement the derivation, analysis, and application of the model, we have advanced theory to understand the role of the interconnection topology, i.e., which animal is sensing and responding to which other animal, in the collective motion and behavior of the group.  We derived new systematic ways to identify which individuals have more influence on the group by virtue of their location in the graph that encodes the interconnection topology.  We made this rigorous by computing individual and group-level performance measures as a function of measures of the interaction graph.  We proved what kinds of centrality measures distinguish individuals and predict individual-level and group-level dynamics and performance.  For robustness of a collective decision in response to an unknown and noisy external signal, we showed where in the network should individuals be who pay close attention to the external signal in order that the group as a whole can most accurately respond to the signal, even if the remaining animals ignore the external signal in favor of relying on social cues from those nearby. Conditions for poor performance may be indicative of vulnerability of the group to a predator attack, and the derivation of these conditions can be used to guide observational strategies in field studies.

We have collaborated with our colleagues at the National Geographic Society and the University of Maryland to design, prepare for, and carry out field studies using the crittercams with: 1) white-tailed deer at the Smithsonian research center at Front Royal, VA and 2) antelope and African buffalo at Gorongosa National Park in Mozambique.

Our results have been disseminated in refereed conference papers, 6 journal papers, conference presentations, keynote lectures, university seminars, workshops, tutorial sessions, and school presentations.  Two graduate students have earned their PhD’s as part of this project and have gone on to excellent postdoctoral positions.

We have provided rigorous means to systematically infer how the behavior and interactions of individual agents in animal aggregations affect group-level outcomes. This informs the engineering disciplines associated with design of animal-borne wireless networks and design of mobile multi-agent systems.  It also impacts biology by providing new methods for developing insight and predictive modeling of collective animal behavior.
